pull.title: ci: Check for submodules
pull.body:
See #18019.
The current solution looks like this (I also tested with multiple submodules):
```
These submodules were found, delete them:
 355a5a310019659d9bf6818d2fd66fbb214dfed7 curl (curl-7_68_0-108-g355a5a310)
```
The submodule example command was `git submodule add https://github.com/curl/curl.git curl`

events.body:
Concept ACK, thanks for working on this.

Wouldn't it be preferable to ask `git` directly with `git submodule status` instead of looking for `.gitmodules` (which is an implementation detail)?

Concept ACK
Agree with @laanwj. Looking for .gitmodule feels like a tiny layer violation.
Ok, will switch to a git(1) based solution. Don't have that much time today so I don't know if I can do it right now.

Updated the script with a git based solution.
If a submodule was found it'll look like this (I used https://github.com/curl/curl.git in this example)
```
Delete the submodules:
5ce7102ceae250e2d31b54aad2f33b3bc35f243a curl (curl-7_68_0-99-g5ce7102ce)
```

Thanks for updating this to use git
ACK

tree 12f0293f4a20d9e0487e926e8eaee66f7f97007d
parent 6d0e532ae029cb687258f8cdd43d7f9f3cfaa900
author Emil Engler <me@emilengler.com> 1580674720 +0100
committer Emil Engler <me@emilengler.com> 1581349695 +0100

ci: Check for submodules

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/bin/sh
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(find . -type f | grep .gitmodules)
+RESULT=$?
+if [ $RESULT = 0 ]
+then
+    echo Delete the submodules:
+    echo $CMD
+    EXIT_CODE=1
+fi
+
+exit $EXIT_CODE

@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/bin/sh
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(find . -type f | grep .gitmodules)
comments.body: What if this is executed in test folder?

Why use bash for it?
sh does the same and is more cross platform

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/bin/sh
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(find . -type f | grep .gitmodules)
comments.body: Then it will only look for .gitmodules in the test folder. Is there a way to go to the root dir?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
comments.body: It will be nice having here a description (smth like "`# Check for git submodules.`") following an empty line (see other scripts in this subdir as an example).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
comments.body:
```suggestion
CMD=$(git submodule status)
```

If this script reports submodules which should be _deleted_, it should not list nested ones.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
+if [[ ${CMD} ]]
+then
comments.body:
nit: `if test -n "$CMD"; then` seems more explicit.
nit: curly braces are redundant here.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
+if [[ ${CMD} ]]
+then
+    echo These submodules were found, delete them:
+    echo $CMD
comments.body:
```suggestion
    echo "$CMD"
```

...otherwise, script will print multiple submodules in a line.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@

+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying

@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
comments.body:
If an "outer" submodule will be deleted, the nested submodule will be deleted automatically (as it resides in the subdirectory of the "outer" submodule), no?

It seems no need in "delete them" instruction to a user point to nested submodules.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@

+#
+# This script checks for git modules
comments.body: post-hom: Probably should leave a sentence saying why it's erroring if it does and what the alternative is for implementers :)
